Delicia Pilar, 36, is an enterprising woman who struggles to reach her ideals. She lives in Pucallpa, Ucayali region. She runs a grocery store from her home. She tends to it daily so she rises very early to open her store. Her husband, who is a merchant, supports her efforts. Pilar has been a member of the "De la Amistad" communal bank for 11 years. Her first, 300 sol, loan was used to buy soft-drinks. She now needs a 700 sol loan to buy stock items like pasta, sugar, soft-drinks, detergent, oil, etc. to sell to her customers. Pilar's goal is to stock her store with different types of articles like hardware, office and household supplies.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy stock items like pasta, sugar, soft-drinks, detergent, oil, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Loan to strengthen their businesses.

loans.name: La Camacha Group

texts.es:
Este grupo solidario se llama LA CAMACHA   porque asi  se llama  la población donde viven.  Está ubicado en el municipio de Tlalixcoyan en el estado de Veracruz.  El grupo está conformado por   5  integrantes que se conocen desde hace tiempo pues viven en la misma comunidad.  Éste es su primer  préstamo con Fundación Realidad.

La representante del grupo se llama  Reynalda L. L.,  es soltera, tiene 50 años, estudió  la universidad, y tiene en total 5 hijos 3 mujeres y 2 varones.  Ella se dedica a la crianza de cerdos y necesita el préstamo para comprar cerdas para la cría y alimento para mantenerlos. Ella tiene sus cerdos en el patio de su solar.  Reynalda L. L.   desea este préstamo para aumentar su negocio, para así obtener una ganancia mayor y volver a invertir en mas cerdos.

Rusbelly L. L. también está en el grupo LA CAMACHA  Ella tiene 39 , estudió hasta la universidad , y tiene en total 2  hijos 1mujer y 1 varon.  Ella  se dedica a la cría de cerdos y necesita el préstamo para comprar alimento para  mantener sus cerdos .  Rusbelly mantiene sus cerdos en el patio del solar de su mama  con quien vive.
Rusbelly desea este préstamo para aumentar su negocio,  para que con las ganancias que obtenga poder comprar  un terreno para construir su casa ya que actualmente ella vive con su mama.

Los otros 3 integrantes se llaman Fabian H. L. , Hector  M. E. y Alejandrina E. Raygoza, y quieren préstamos para invertir en sus negocios como son, venta de abarrotes , y la cria y engorda de cerdos.
texts.en:
This group is called "La Camacha" because this is the name of the town where they live. It is located in the municipality of Tlalixcoyan in the state of Veracruz. This group is formed by 5 members who know each other since they have lived in the same community for a long time. This is their first loan with the Realidad Foundation. The representative of the group is named Reynalda L. L.. She is single, 50 years old, and studied at the university. She has a total of 5 children: 3 daughters and 2 sons. She raises pigs and needs the loan to buy pigs to raise and food to maintain them. She keeps her pigs in a yard on her property. Reynalda L. L. wants this loan to increase her business, in order to obtain higher earnings and be able to reinvest in more pigs. Rusbelly L. L. is also in the group La Camacha. She is 39, and studied until the university. She has 2 children: a son and a daughter. She raises pigs and needs a loan to buy food for her pigs. Rusbelly keeps her pigs in a yard on her mother's property where she lives. Rusbelly wants the loan to increase her business, so that with the earnings she can buy a plot of land where she can build her house, since she currently lives with her mother. The other 3 members of the group are named Fabian H. L. , Hector M. E. and Alejandrina E. Raygoza. They want loans to invest in their businesses: they sell groceries and breed and raise pigs.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy pigs

loans.name: Ana  Celina

texts.es: Doña Ana Celina es una mujer muy esforzada y trabajadora, tiene 32 años de edad, procreo tres hijos, los tres estudiantes que junto con su esposo esperan poder apoyarlos para que logren terminar sus estudios. Su negocio es el Alquiler de cuartos que junto con su esposo administran, anteriormente se dedicaba a la venta de comida en un mercado, su casa ha mejorado grandemente gracias a los financiamiento que Afodenic a dado pues para personas de poco recursos económico es el mejor medio de poder prosperar, muy agradecida con  Dios por que ha logrado tener su casa en mejores condiciones, y mejor seguridad para sus pequeños hijos así como mejor higiene. Con este préstamo seguirá invirtiendo en la compra de materiales de construcción como: piedra, arena, cemento, hierro para hacer un porche,  ya tiene un bajarete, y quiere cerrarlo y repellar las paredes para que se le mire bonita su casa. Sus planes es ponerle piso después ya que es de tierra el cual espera lograrlo a corto plazo con el apoyo de su esposo como el de la institución.
texts.en:
Ana Celina, 32, is a hard-working woman. She has three children, all of whom are in school. Together with her husband, she hopes to help them finish their studies. She and her husband rent out rooms. She used to sell prepared meals in a market. Her house has improved considerably thanks to the financing that Afodenic gives to low-income persons; it is the best way that one can prosper. She is very grateful to God because she has managed to improve her home providing both better security and hygiene for her little ones. This funding will be used to buy building materials like: sand, stone, cement and iron, to build a porch because it's just a mud wall. She wants to enclose it and plaster the walls so that her house will have a pleasant appearance. Later on, she plans to install flooring because it's currently a dirt floor; she hopes to do this in the short run with help from her husband and the institution.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy stone, sand, cement and iron to build a porch.

loans.name: Johnson Street Business Center Group

texts.en:
Augustine S. is the leader of this group of five borrowers called Johnson Street Business Center. In the photo, Augustine is the one holding the sign. He is 56 years old, married, and is a high school graduate. He has seven children who range in age from 13 to 35.

For eight years, Augustine has had a building-materials business on Johnson Street. He says that he provides high quality service in a friendly manner, which attracts customers.

Augustine plans to use his 14,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 56,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more building materials such as planks, nails and cement. His goal is to grow his business, to help his children go to school, and to build a house.


About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more construction supplies to sell
